forecast.rationale:
The status quo strongly favors a YES outcome. Currently, 14.5 million Florida residents (73.9% of the population) are in drought conditions, providing a buffer of 0.5 million residents above the threshold. The research assistant's report indicates severe conditions: 84% of the state is under moderate to extreme drought (worst since 2012), the state experienced its 12th driest April-to-March period since 1895, and some regions are 6-10 inches below average rainfall since mid-October 2024. 

The key question is whether conditions can improve enough in just 30 days to drop below the threshold. While June marks the beginning of Florida's wet season (typically May/June through October), several factors suggest drought persistence is more likely: (1) Drought conditions built over 7-8 months and typically require sustained rainfall over weeks or months to resolve; (2) Drought Monitor classifications are updated weekly but tend to be 'sticky,' changing gradually unless exceptional rainfall occurs; (3) Even with wet season rainfall, soil moisture recovery, aquifer recharge, and classification updates lag behind precipitation events; (4) The deep rainfall deficit requires substantial precipitation to overcome.

The main uncertainty is whether Florida experiences exceptional June rainfall from tropical systems or an aggressive wet season onset. However, even early wet season rainfall doesn't guarantee immediate drought designation changes. The small buffer (2.5% of population) does create some vulnerability if conditions improve moderately.

My forecast is not higher (toward 90%+) because: the wet season is beginning, creating real possibility of significant rainfall; the buffer is relatively small; and one month allows for 4-5 drought monitor updates. My forecast is not lower (toward 50-60%) because: drought conditions are severe and well-established; 30 days is short for meaningful drought recovery; and status quo persistence is the baseline expectation. I would update higher with evidence of continued dry conditions or delayed wet season, and lower with forecasts of major tropical systems or exceptional early rainfall.
